Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 52412: Direct Insurance (except Life, Health, and Medical) Carriers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: ING Life Insurance and Annuity Co.
Description: The U.S. Department of Labor announced a settlement agreement with ING Life Insurance and Annuity Co. that provided for a $5.2 million payment to certain retirement plan clients adversely affected by its undisclosed practice of keeping investment gains achieved when the company failed to process requested transactions in a timely manner.

Private Litigation Case Title: Healthcare Strategies, Inc. v. ING Life Insurance & Annuity Co.
Sewright v. ING Groep N.V. et al

Description: The attorneys general of New York and New Hampshire announced an agreement with ING designed to set new national standards for transparency in the marketing of retirement products. It also provided compensation to teachers whose union had received payments from ING to promote its annuity plans.

Company: ING Life Insurance and Annuity Company
Description: ING Life agreed to pay $10.7 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Florida Announces a Multi-State, Multi-Agency Life Claim Settlement Agreement with ING Life Insurance and Annuity Company, Targeted News Service, August 19, 2013 (via Nexis).

Company: ING USA Annuity and Life Insurance Co.
Voya Financial Advisors, Inc. fka ING Financial Partners, Inc.
Description: Voya Financial Advisors agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty and $915,000 in restitution in settlement of allegations it failed to properly supervise its agents and operations, leading to investors losing money by being sold unregistered securities.
Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Company: Security Life of Denver Insurance Co.

Description: ING agreed to make restitution offers of $4,567,326 to customers and pay $110,000 to the Securities Investor Education Fund in settlement of allegations it failed to adequately supervise two of its dealers who were convicted for theft of investors' funds.

Notes: Disciplinary action for violations disclosed in a Consent Order with the State of New Jersey

Company: ING Life Insurance and Annuity Co. et al.
Description: ING Life Insurance  and Annuity Company, Reliastar Life Insurance Company of New  York, Midwestern United Life Insurance Company, Reliastar Life Insurance Company, Security Life of Denver Insurance Company, and ING USA Annuity and Life Insurance Company agreed to pay a $200,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations their previous use of the automatic default option establishing a retained asset account could result in an unsuitable arrangement for a beneficiary, in violation of state regulations.

Company: Voya Insurance and Annuity Co. et al.
Description: Voya Insurance and Annuity Company fka ING USA Annuity and Life Insurance Company, Voya Retirement Insurance and Annuity Company fka ING Life Insurance  and Annuity Company, Midwestern United Life Insurance Company, ReliaStar Life Insurance Company, ReliaStar Life Insurance Company Of New York, and Security Life of Denver Insurance Company, agreed to pay $1.25 million to the state as part of a settlement of allegations they had inadequate procedures to ensure policies and other funds were timely investigated and paid out to beneficiaries.

Company: ING Life Insurance and Annuity Company
Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Company: ING Life Insurance and Annuity Company
Security Life of Denver Insurance Company

Description: These proceedings arise from Voya's alleged breach of its fiduciary duties to its advisory clients in connection with: (a) Voya's mutual fund share class selection practices and the financial benefits it received for advising clients to purchase and hold mutual fund share classes that paid fees pursuant to Rule 12b-1 under the Investment Company Act of 1940; (b) Voya's receipt of compensation in connection with certain client cash sweep accounts; and (c) Voya's policy of requiring advisory clients to pay an upfront brokerage commission when purchasing illiquid alternative investment products when the same investment was available to advisory clients with the brokerage commissions waived.
The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined eight firms for failing to supervise sales of variable annuities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined five affiliates of ING $1.2 million for failing to retain or review millions of emails for periods ranging from two months to more than six years. The five firms were Directed Services, LLC; ING America Equities, Inc.; ING Financial Advisers, LLC; ING Financial Partners, Inc.; and ING Investment Advisors, LLC.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD announced a total of $7 million in fines against four broker-dealers affiliated with ING America Insurance Holdings, Inc. (ING) in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered ING Funds Distributor to pay a fine of $1.5 million for permitting improper market timing in ING funds and related violations.
Info Source: NASD Orders ING Funds Distributor to Pay $1.5 Million Fine, $1.4 Million in Restitution for Permitting Improper Market Timing, PR Newswire, October 3, 2005 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: ReliaStar Life Insurance Company of New York
Description: ReliaStar agreed to pay $169,000 in settlement of allegations the company failed to examine and ascertain that the Disclosure Statement was accurate and met the requirements of Insurance Regulation  and failed to obtain a signed acknowledgement by the applicant of receipt of a revised Disclosure Statement,when the life insurance policy differed from the life insurance policy initially applied for.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services
